p: Five volatile compounds, namely, curzerene ( 98) (6.6 mg), β-elemene ( 100, Fig. 12) (5.1 mg), curzerenone ( 126) (41.6 mg), curcumenol ( 127) (46.2 mg), and curcumenone ( 128) (21.2 mg) (Fig. 17), were separated from the methanol extract of Curcuma Rhizome by Prep-GC over a stainless steel column packed with 10% OV-101 (3 m × 6 mm, i.d.) after 83 single injections (20 μl) [ 87]. Prep-GC was also applied for the separation of natural isomers. A total of 178 mg of cis-asarone ( 129) and 82 mg of trans-asarone ( 130) were obtained from the essential oil of Acorus tatarinowii after 90 single injections (5 μl) on the same column as above [ 88]. Prep-GC has become an important separation method for natural volatile compounds; however, a heavier sample load and the large-diameter preparative column employed decreased the efficiency [ 89]. Meanwhile, the disadvantages of Prep-GC, including the lack of commercial Prep-GC equipment, consumption of a large volume of carrier gas, the decomposition of thermolabile compounds under high operation temperature, the difficulties of fraction collection, and low production, still restrict the usage of Prep-GC.
